contextId.information: Isaiah uses these questions to scold the people of Judah. The questions can be translated as statements. This can also be stated in active form. AT: "You keep doing things that Yahweh has to punish you for. You continue to rebel against him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Why are you still being beaten? Why do you rebel more and more?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this question in order to accuse the leaders of the people. This accusation can be expressed as a statement. AT: "I am angry with you evil men because you are crushing my people and grinding the faces of the poor!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you crush my people and grind the faces of the poor?

contextId.information: These questions are to show that people could consult God instead of the foolish activity of trying to talk to dead people. AT: "But people should ask Yahweh to guide them. They should not seek answers from those who have died." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: But should a people not consult their God? Should they consult the dead on behalf of the living?

contextId.information: Isaiah uses a question to scold those in Judah who harm the poor and weak people. AT: "You will be able to do nothing on judgment day ... away!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What will you do on judgment day ... away?

contextId.information: The king of Assyria uses a question to emphasize what he believes everyone should already know. AT: "I have made captains of my army kings over lands I have conquered!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are not all my princes kings?

contextId.information: The speaker uses these questions to mock the king of Assyria. AT: "An ax cannot boast that it is better than the one who holds it. And a saw does not get more glory than the one who cuts with it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will the ax boast about itself against the one who wields it? Will the saw praise itself more than the one who cuts with it?

contextId.information: This question is used to say that no one can turn back God's hand. Turning back his hand represents stopping him from punishing the nations. AT: "no one can turn it back." or "no one can stop him from punishing them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who will turn it back?

contextId.information: The author uses this question to introduce his instruction about how the Israelites should speak to the messengers. AT: "This is how we will answer the messengers of Philistia." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How then will one answer the messengers of that nation?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to mock Tyre. This rhetorical questions can be translated as a statement. AT: "This has indeed happened to you who were full of joy in the ancient city of Tyre ... to settle." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Has this happened to you, the joyful city, whose origin is from ancient times ... to settle?

contextId.information: Isaiah uses a question to mock Tyre. The word "this" refers to God's plans to destroy Tyre which Isaiah described in 23:1-7. Also, "Tyre" refers to the people who live in Tyre. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "It was Yahweh who has planned to destroy the people of Tyre ... of the earth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Who has planned this against Tyre ... of the earth?

contextId.information: The question is used to contrast the severity of God's punishment. AT: "Yahweh has certainly punished the enemy nations more severely than he punished the people of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Has Yahweh attacked Jacob and Israel as he attacked those nations who attacked them?

contextId.information: Isaiah uses rhetorical questions to make the people think deeply. AT: "A farmer does not plow the ground over and over and continually work the soil without ever sowing seed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Does a farmer who plows all day to sow, only plow the ground? Does he continually break up and harrow the field?

contextId.information: These rhetorical question are asked to emphasize that the Assyrian officials are gone. These questions may be written as statements. AT: "The officers of Assyria who counted the tax money that we were forced to pay to them have disappeared! Those men who counted our towers are gone!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: where is the scribe, where is he who weighed the money? Where is he who counted the towers?

contextId.information: The king of Assyria uses this question to challenge Hezekiah and to say that he does not have a good source for confidence. This question may be written as a statement. AT: "You have no reliable source for your confidence." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What is the source of your confidence?

contextId.information: The king of Assyria uses questions to ridicule Hezekiah for believing he has the strength to rebel. This question may be written as a statement. AT: "No matter in whom you trust, you will not have the courage to rebel against me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Now in whom are you trusting? Who has given you courage to rebel against me?

contextId.information: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule the people and to imply that Yahweh was angry about what Hezekiah did and would not protect them. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "he is the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah has taken away ... Jerusalem" or "he is the one whom Hezekiah insulted by tearing down his high places and altars ... Jerusalem." (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: is not he the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah has taken away ... Jerusalem"?

contextId.information: The chief commander continues to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. When he says "you," referring to Hezekiah, he is actually referring to Hezekiah's army. This question may be written as a statement. AT: "Your army could not even defeat one captain ... servants." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: How could you resist even one captain ... servants?

contextId.information: The chief commander uses this question to emphasize his insult. This can be written as a statement. AT: "My master has sent me to everyone who hears this, who will have to ... you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Has he not sent me to the men who sit on the wall, who will have to ... you?

contextId.information: The chief commander uses this question to ridicule the people of Judah. This question may be written as a statement. AT: "None of the gods of the peoples rescued them from ... Assyria." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Has any of the gods of the peoples rescued them from ... Assyria?

contextId.information: The chief commander uses these questions to ridicule the people of Judah. These questions may be combined and written as a statement. AT: "The gods of Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, and Samaria did not rescue their people from my power." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they rescued Samaria from my power?

contextId.information: The chief commander uses this question to ridicule the people of Judah. This question may be written as a statement. AT: "there is no god who has rescued ... and Yahweh will not save you in Jerusalem from my power." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: is there any god who has rescued ... as if Yahweh could save Jerusalem from my power?

contextId.information: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. This may be written as a statement. AT: "So you too will not be saved." or "So of course no one will rescue you either!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: So will you be rescued?

contextId.information: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. This may be written as a statement. AT: "We also conquered the king ... Ivvah!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Where is the king ... Ivvah?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to remind Sennacherib of information that he should already be aware of. This can be written as a statement. AT: "Certainly you have heard how ... times." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you not heard how ... times?

contextId.information: Hezekiah uses a question to emphasize he has nothing left to say. This can be written as a statement. AT: "I have nothing left to say." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What shall I say?

contextId.information: These rhetorical questions anticipate a negative answer and emphasize that only Yahweh is able to do these things. AT: "No one but Yahweh has measured ... and the hills in a balance." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who has measured ... or the hills in a balance?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question anticipates a negative answer and emphasizes that no one is able to do these things. AT: "No one has comprehended the mind of Yahweh, and no one has instructed him as his counselor." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who has comprehended the mind of Yahweh, or instructed him as his counselor?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question anticipates a negative answer and emphasizes that no one has ever done this. AT: "He has never received instruction from anyone." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: From whom did he ever receive instruction?

contextId.information: Isaiah uses two similar questions to emphasize that there is no idol that can compare with God. AT: "There is no one to whom you can compare God. There is no idol to which you can liken him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: To whom then will you compare God? To what idol will you liken him?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses two similar rhetorical questions to emphasize that there is no one like him. AT: "There is no one to whom you can compare me. There is no one whom I resemble." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: To whom then will you compare me, whom do I resemble?

contextId.information: The question emphasizes that they should not say what they say. AT: "'You should not say, O people of Israel ... vindication'." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you say, Jacob, and declare, Israel ... vindication"?

contextId.information: Isaiah uses these questions to emphasize that the people should know Yahweh's greatness. See how you translated these in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:40:21|40:21]]. AT: "You certainly know and have heard!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you not known? Have you not heard?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he is the one who caused this ruler from the east to be victorious. AT: "I am the one who called this powerful ruler from the east and put him in my good service." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who has stirred up one from the east, calling him in righteousness to his service?

contextId.information: Here the word "generations" represents all of human history, which Yahweh created and directed throughout history. The rhetorical question anticipates the answer, Yahweh. AT: "I have summoned the generations of humanity from the beginning." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who has summoned the generations from the beginning?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses these rhetorical questions to mock the idols that the people worship. The implied answers are 1) that the idols have not done these things and 2) that Yahweh is the one who has done these things. AT: "None of the idols announced this from the beginning, that we might know. And none of them announced this before time, that we may say, 'He is right.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and[[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: Who announced this from the beginning, that we might know? Before this time, that we may say, "He is right"?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks these rhetorical questions to scold his people and to emphasize that no one is as blind or deaf as they are. AT: "No one is as blind as my servant. No one is as deaf as my messenger whom I send." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who is blind but my servant? Or deaf like my messenger I send?

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing. Isaiah uses this as a leading question in order to emphasize the answer that he will give in the next phrase. AT: "I will tell you who gave the people of Israel over to robbers and looters." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Who gave Jacob over to the robber, and Israel to the looters?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to teach the people of Israel. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "surely you have noticed it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: do you not perceive it?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that there is no one like him. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "If anyone thinks he is like me, let him announce" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who is like me? Let him announce

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he is the one who predicted the events that have now happened. This can be translated as a statement. The word "announced" means basically the same thing as "declared." AT: "I declared these things to you long ago." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: Have I not declared to you long ago, and announced it?

contextId.information: Yahweh is using this question to rebuke those who make idols. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Only fools would form a god or cast an idol that is worthless." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who would form a god or cast an idol that is worthless?

contextId.information: Yahweh says that these people should be asking themselves these rhetorical questions. The questions anticipate negative answers and emphasize how foolish it would be for a person to do these things. These questions can be translated as statements. AT: "I should not now make ... something disgusting to worship. I should not bow down to a block of wood." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Now should I make ... something disgusting to worship? Should I bow down to a block of wood?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people of Israel for not admitting what they should know is true. AT: "you are stubborn and will not admit what I said is true." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: will you not admit what I said is true?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that the idols have not told them these things. AT: "None of your idols has told this to you." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who among you has announced these things?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to help his people understand that he will never forget about them or stop caring for them. AT: "A woman would not forget her nursing baby or stop caring for the son she bore." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can a woman forget her baby, nursing at her breast, so she does not have compassion on the son she has borne?

contextId.information: Isaiah uses a question to express the difficulty of taking anything from a mighty soldier or a very strong warrior. This can be stated in active form. AT: "A person cannot take the spoils from a warrior or rescue captives from fierce soldiers." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Can the spoils be taken from the warrior, or captives be rescued from the fierce?

contextId.information: The servant uses these questions to emphasize that there is no one who can legitimately accuse him of wrong. AT: "If anyone would oppose me, let us stand ... If anyone would accuse me, let him come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who will oppose me? Let us stand ... Who is my accuser? Let him come

contextId.information: Again, the speaker uses questions to emphasize Yahweh's power to do mighty things. This refers to Yahweh opening the Red Sea for the Israelites to cross and escape the army of Egypt. AT: "You dried up the sea ... for the redeemed to pass through." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did you not dry up the sea ... for the redeemed to pass through?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that they should not forget Yahweh. This may be written as a statement. AT: "You should not have forgotten Yahweh ... earth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why have you forgotten Yahweh ... earth?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that the people should not fear those who want to oppress them. Their oppressors are no longer a threat to them. This may be written as a statement. AT: "The fury of the oppressor is not a threat!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Where is the fury of the oppressor?

contextId.information: Isaiah uses questions to emphasize that now there is no one to weep with them or comfort them. These questions may be written as statements. AT: "but there is no one to grieve with you ... There is no one to comfort you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: who will grieve with you? ... Who will comfort you?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to make the people pay attention to what he is about to say. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Now look at what is happening ... my people are again taken away for nothing." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Now what do I have here ... seeing that my people are taken away for nothing?

contextId.information: This question emphasizes that no one thinks about him. AT: "no one from his generation cared what happened to him" or "no one among his contemporaries cared what happened to him " (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: who from that generation thought anymore about him?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke the people. He speaks of them seeking happiness apart from Yahweh as if they were working to earn money to buy things that could not satisfy them. AT: "you should not be working for money to spend on things that do not satisfy." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: why do you labor for what does not satisfy?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses these questions to scold the people. AT: "You must really fear these idols for you to act so deceitfully ... about me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Whom are you worried about? Whom do you fear so much that has caused you to act so deceitfully ... about me?

contextId.information: The people of Israel use questions to complain to God because they feel he is ignoring them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: 'Why have we fasted,' they say, 'but you do not see it? Why have we humbled ourselves, but you do not notice?'

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people. They act like they are humble before God, but they are hurting other people. AT: "This is not the kind of fast I want ... under himself." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is this really the kind of fast that I would want ... under himself?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people. AT: "Surely you do not think this kind of fast pleases me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you really call this a fast, a day that pleases Yahweh?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to teach the people about the kind of fast that pleases him. AT: "This is the fast that I choose ... break every yoke." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is not this the fast that I choose ... break every yoke?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses another question to teach the people. AT: "It is to ... your house." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is it not to ... your house?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses questions and poetic images to draw attention here. He compares the sails of the ships to clouds and doves. This is also a picture of the Israelites returning to the country where they belong. AT: "Look, I see something like clouds moving quickly and like doves returning to their shelters." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Who are these who fly along like a cloud, and like the doves to their shelters?

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks as a watchman using the question and answer format to present this information about Yahweh's judgment on Edom, an enemy of Israel. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "I, Yahweh, am coming from Edom, clothed in red from Bozrah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who is this who comes from Edom ... Bozrah

contextId.information: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "The red on your clothing looks makes you look like you have been treading on grapes in a winepress." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why are your clothes red, and why ... winepress?

contextId.information: Here the writer uses a question to express a complaint of the people to God. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Yahweh, you have made us wander from your ways and become stubborn so that we do not obey you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh, why do you make us wander from your ways and harden our hearts, so we do not obey you?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize that he will not fail to fulfill his promises to the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do I bring a baby to the birth opening ... born?
